Now Trump ’ s White House Receives the Statue of Liberty
The surest sign of regime change is when they start attacking the statues .
Americans appreciate it as much as anyone else - hence the carefully staged overthrow of Saddam Hussein in Baghdad in 2003 .

Stephen Miller , one of the Trump regime ’ s key ideologues , certainly knew what he did when he took a symbolic axe in a heated dispute with CNN ’ s Jim Acosta about the president ’ s proposals to radically restrict legal immigration to the Statue of Liberty .
To remain fair , Miller did not attack the statue itself .
A horde of boat owners and liberty-Imitators would have laughed him if he had done so .

But it took on its significance , and in particular the importance attributed to it when the famous poem of Emma Lazarus was added to its base in 1903 , 17 years after the completion of the monument .
As Miller Acosta complained , " I don 't want to go into a complete story here , but the Statue of Liberty is ... a symbol of American freedom that illuminates the world .
The poem to which you refer , which was added later and is not part of the original Statue of Liberty . '
Miller is factually correct , but , as he himself put it , it is not really about history .

It is about the contemporary response to Lazarus 's stirring words , the only one in which a state invites not only any old immigrants , but the poorest of the poor : " Your mosquitoes , your poor , / your oppressed masses who yearn to breathe freely / the wretched waste of your rich coasts . "
There was never a time when the ' miserable waste ' was better to see on our screens .
Miller did not engage in literary criticism – he made it clear that these people are not welcome in Trump ’ s US .
This conflict over the importance of a statue is part of a broader political and cultural debate : it is indeed a conflict over America ’ s importance .
Lazarus - and her friends who fought to place their words on the ground after their death - knew very well that they were carrying out a highly political act .
The sculpture should show the links between French and American Republicanism by portraying the female embodiment of freedom in a worn classical depiction .
Lazarus changed this meaning : In her poem the female figure is no longer abstract - she has received a voice .
And she gives herself a very different name : mother of exiles .
The combination of the poem and the image is a brilliant feminist coup and a devastating attack on American nativism .
And just as Lazarus changed the meaning of the statue , people from the right wing wanted to change it a long time ago .

The great shrine of Rush Limbaugh , a kind of John the Baptist for Trump ’ s coming , argued in 2010 that the Statue of Liberty was not inviting anyone , but rather an early neo-conservative who brought the American flame into the surrounding world : " Lady Liberty is moving forward .
It is supposed to carry the torch of freedom from the United States to the rest of the world .
The torch is not supposed to light the way to the United States . '
Limbaugh came across something quite unusual .
The importance of the statue is quite a question of the position of perception .
The great fanciful act of Lazarus was to see it as it was seen by the exhausted , wretched but hopeful people after long and often terrible journeys on the decks of ships .
It is truly a question of seeing the world from the perspective of people seeking refuge and an opportunity to improve their lives .
Their statue speaks to them the words of hope and the welcome they must hear .
And that , of course , is not the perspective that Miller and Trump ever want to recognize .
Their torch is not intended to light the path , but to inflame the hatred that is their only source of power .

Poverty and Death in Indonesia ’ s Gold Country
When Bardina Degi cooks dinner , she does not use a stove .
It even rarely uses a pot .

In her wooden house in Enarotali , the capital of the Paniai regency in the troubled Indonesian province of Papua , the housewife usually puts a sweet potato - locally called " nota " - directly into the fireplace .
After half an hour the charred bulb is taken from and swallowed with eager , unashed hands .
Degi sits on the clay floor - she has no furniture - where she also performs her daily work , for example washing clothes with cloudy water from the nearby swamp .
A bucket in a roofless room serves as a latrine .
As the youngest of her husband 's four wives , she was not assigned any fields .
Polygamy is common here .
Of course , late to work can be dangerous : most villagers are unemployed , and many drink hard , and there are soldiers here .
Nobody dares to walk around in the village after 5 p.m.  she says .

It is a rare insight into daily life in the highlands of Papua , a former Dutch colony , which was admitted in 1969 after a controversial referendum in Indonesia , when only 1,026 elders were to vote in front of the occupying forces through a public hand survey .
An existing movement that stirred up independence against Dutch rule quickly turned against the Jakarta government , which controls the region and excludes foreign journalists or legal observers .
In 2003 , the province was officially divided into Papua and West Papua , with the independent part of Papua New Guinea covering the eastern part of the island .
Enarotali is as remote as it might be .
There is no public transport .
The city of about 19,000 inhabitants consists of wooden houses surrounded by bamboo fences and corrugated iron roofs transformed by rust into various yellow-brown tones .
Few Indonesians have travelled here , let alone journalists and virtually no foreigners .
Before Christian missionaries arrived , Mee Pago Papuans worshipped a god called Uga Tamee .
There have also been other changes .
We were not used to wearing this dress ,  says Degi , pointing to her lively , hand-woven turban , her dark shirt and her bright skirt .
'In the past , we had only leaves on our bodies . '
Papua is Indonesia ’ s poorest province , where 28 % of people live below the poverty line and have some of the worst child mortality and literacy rates in Asia .
But it is also Indonesia ’ s goldland .
The largest and most profitable gold mine in the world , Grasberg , owned by the Phoenix Freeport McMoran , is only 60 miles from Paniai , a highland province of New Jersey with 153,000 inhabitants .
In 2015 alone , Freeport lost $ 3.1 billion in gold and copper .
Papua also has an estimated $ 78 billion in timber resources .
But this wealth is a source of misery for the Papua , who ensure that Indonesia ’ s powerful military maintains a stifling presence .
A 2005 survey in the New York Times reported that Freeport paid nearly $ 20 million to local military personnel and units between 1998 and 2004 , including up to $ 150,000 to a single officer .
Papuan demands for greater autonomy threaten these golden gans and are treated mercilessly .
According to activists , more than 500,000 Papua have been killed and thousands have been raped , tortured and imprisoned by the Indonesian military since 1969 .
Mass killings in Papua ’ s tribal highlands in the 1970 ’ s became genocide under the Asian Human Rights Commission .
In the region alone , the Indonesian police arrested more than 3,900 peaceful demonstrators last year .

We Are All Losing  is stated in a 2016 report by the Archdiocese of Brisbane , which contains reports of last year 's atrocities , such as unlawful executions and torture - rape and electrical strikes are particularly popular after another report - and the brutal crackdown on peaceful demonstrations .
It is difficult to count the number of victims because incidents happen every week ,  says Andreas Harsono , Indonesia 's Human Rights Watch researcher .
The bolts have intensified as Papua 's resources bring an influx of settlers from other parts of Indonesia .

The population of 3.5 million inhabitants of the province is 83 % Christian , but demographic changes as Muslim economic migrants come from the populous islands of Java , Borneo , Sumatra , and Sulawesi .
Javanese canteens sell fried chicken and Gado , a mixed vegetable with peanut sauce served .
Local people are fighting to keep up here .

'It has cost the local Papua - the Mama Mama [ the Women ] of Papua - their market ' .
Indonesian President Joko Widodo , popularly known as Jokowi , promised to address the inequalities and violations in Papua during his 2014 campaign .
The former carpenter secured 27 of the 29 districts of Papua , including Paniai , on his way to the presidential palace in Jakarta .
But little has changed in Papua , and today the locals feel cheated .
Our hearts have broken because we voted for Jokowi in 2014 , with the expectation that he will fulfill our hopes that justice will be restored ,  says You .
Indeed , only two months after Jokowi ’ s inauguration in October , Paniai suffered a low point .
On December 7 , 2014 , a group of 11 children were out and sang Christmas songs in front of a campfire in Enarotali , when two Indonesian soldiers broke through the darkness on a motorcycle .
The frightened children told them that they should turn on their headlights .
One of the soldiers took offense at their tone and came back later with four soldiers , according to the local pastor Yavedt Tebai .
The soldiers who had drunk hunted and beat the group with their rifles , said victims and witnesses .
Then one of the soldiers fired into the group of children .
A child , the 16-year-old Yulianus Yeimo , was so badly beaten that he fell into the coma .
A few hours later , the building of the nearby government commission was set on fire , and things escalated the next day .
Approximately 1,000 young Papua men , women , and children gathered in a football pitch in front of the local police station and the military commando center to demand justice .
They wore ceremonial hunting arches and performed the Waita dance - continuously in circle and imitating a bird song - by Papua 's Mee Pago tribe .
Some demonstrators began to throw stones on police and military posts .

When the mood was heated , a command was sent to the soldiers via an internal radio : " If the masses resist more than three times , they shoot them dead , " says a TIME official document that was not released to the local media .
